Award.AbstractNarration:
In order to plan for adaptation to climate change, it is important to develop quantitative tools for the uncertainty of climate projections at global, region, and local levels. In this research we develop statistical tools that will let decision-makers get a clearer perspective on how to interpret the projections. For example, we predict (with attendant uncertainty) temperatures at unobserved sites, given that an observed site achieved the network maximum or minimum.

The technical tools used in this research include empirical process models for nonstationary and dependent observations. Data will include global temperature reconstructions, networks of temperature and precipitation stations from Sweden, Norway and the United States, and CMIP5 global model runs as well as regional climate model runs from CORDEX and other repositories. We will also study nonstationary tools in extreme value theory, including spatial and spatio-temporal situations, and implement visualization methods for comparing output from ensembles of climate models to data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main results of this project has been to develop methods to estimate sea level rise from climate models. Most climate models do not directly calculate sea level, but there is a relationship between temperature and sea level that can be used to get sea level from the climate models' temperatures.This has been used as one input among several (such as the relationship between sea surge costs and mean sea level, and the statistical distribution of inundation costs) to inform decision makers who need to build protective barriers for harbors. In spite of enormous uncertainty, it is possible to make informed decisions about what to do and when to do it.

Another aspect of the work has been tools to go from global and regional climate models to local level assessment of future extreme rainfall. The global and regional models do not agree very well with observations, and a correction must be made to improve the agreement. The regional climate models are usually driven by global ones, In order to be able to put future precipitation projections into practical use at a local level (e.g. in order to assess whethercurrent storm drains are sufficient for future weather), it is inecessary to evaluated the quality of local precipitation estimates when letting a weather model drive the regional climate model. It this correction also works when the regional model is driven by a global climate model, this at least indicates that the local future calculations have some value.
